    Small Molecule Mitochondrial Uncouplers and Their Therapeutic Potential

    Miniperspective

    • Elizabeth S. Childress
      Elizabeth S. Childress
      Department of Chemistry and Virginia Tech Center for Drug Discovery, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Virginia 24061, United States
      More by Elizabeth S. Childress
      View Biography
      • , 
    • Stephanie J. Alexopoulos
      Stephanie J. Alexopoulos
      School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW 2033, Australia
      More by Stephanie J. Alexopoulos
      View Biography
      • , 
    • Kyle L. Hoehn
      Kyle L. Hoehn
      School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW 2033, Australia
      Departments of Pharmacology and Medicine, Cardiovascular Research Center, and Emily Couric Clinical Cancer Center, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, Virginia 22908, United States
      More by Kyle L. Hoehn
      View Biography

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Small molecule mitochondrial uncouplers transport protons from the mitochondrial inner membrane space into the mitochondrial matrix independent of ATP synthase, uncoupling nutrient metabolism from ATP generation. The therapeutic potential of mitochondrial uncouplers has been investigated for the treatment of metabolic diseases such as obesity and type 2 diabetes (T2D), ischemia–reperfusion injury, and neurodegenerative diseases. This communication will review the small molecule mitochondrial uncouplers reported to date and explore their potential as therapeutics.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Small molecule mitochondrial uncouplers have a short and turbulent history in the clinic. The small molecule 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP, 1) is the best-studied uncoupler. DNP is a protonophore with activity at mitochondria and other membranes including the plasma membrane. It is estimated that 100 000 patients used DNP as a weight loss drug in the 1930s until it was banned for clinical use in 1938 due to safety concerns. Despite the negative history, there has been a resurgence of interest in mitochondrial uncouplers as therapeutics because studies in rodents show that precise dosing with DNP can extend lifespan and prevent or treat numerous disorders including ischemia–reperfusion injury, neurodegenerative disorders, obesity, and metabolic diseases. These studies present new clinical opportunities for mitochondrial uncouplers. Current strategies for developing small molecule mitochondrial uncouplers as therapeutics have generally focused on either new drug discovery to avoid unwanted off-target activity or making DNP safer by targeting it to mitochondria, targeting it to specific tissues, or formulating it to decrease Cmax. Herein, we review pharmacologic mitochondrial uncouplers with a focus on their chemical properties, potential for therapeutic use, and limitations.

    Coupled Respiration

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Cellular respiration is a physiological process with a fundamental goal of producing energy in the form of ATP. During cellular respiration, chemical energy derived from nutrients is converted into ATP; this process is illustrated in Figure 1. Specifically, the oxidation of nutrients in the mitochondrial matrix generates high-energy electron carriers nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FADH2) that are oxidized by the mitochondrial electron transport chain (ETC) located in the mitochondrial inner membrane (MIM). Electron flow through the ETC is an exergonic process that drives a series of proton pumps to efflux protons from the matrix into the intermembrane space (IMS) against their concentration gradient. The resulting proton concentration (ΔpH) and electrical (ΔΨ) gradient is known as the proton-motive force (pmf).(1,2) Protons that re-enter the mitochondrial matrix via ATP synthase drive endergonic production of ATP. Thus, mitochondrial ATP production involves the coupling of electron transport to phosphorylation reactions via a proton gradient across the MIM.

    Mitochondrial Uncoupling

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Mitochondrial uncoupling describes processes that uncouple nutrient oxidation from ATP production.(3,4) Mitochondrial uncoupling is a normal physiological process that occurs as either basal or inducible proton leak from the intermembrane space. Basal proton leak accounts for ∼20–25% of the basal metabolic rate of mammals.(5) The reason for such metabolic inefficiency is not entirely understood; however, membrane lipid composition and abundance of the adenine nucleotide translocase (ANT) are factors that contribute to basal rates of proton leak. Induced proton leak is driven by reactive species and fatty acids that activate uncoupling proteins (UCPs). UCPs are located in the MIM and facilitate the transfer of protons into the matrix independent of ATP synthase.(6,7)
    There are five known UCPs in mammals, UCP1–5,(8) that have distinct tissue localization and roles reviewed previously.(7−11) The best-characterized UCPs are UCP1 and UCP2.(8,11−13) UCP1 is expressed in brown and beige adipose tissue and has a role in nonshivering thermogenesis.(14) UCP1 is unlikely to operate as a simple proton channel but instead transfers protons via a mechanism that requires long-chain fatty acids.(15) In contrast, UCP2 has a broad tissue distribution and no role in thermogenesis. UCP2 uncouples mitochondria to prevent hyperpolarization and decrease mitochondrial superoxide production.(6)

    Therapeutic Potential of Mitochondrial Uncoupling

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Small molecule mitochondrial uncouplers either act directly as protonophores by transporting protons into the matrix independently of protein complexes or alternatively mediate uncoupling via proteins such as ANT. Protonophoric uncouplers are lipophilic enough to enable passage through the MIM and weakly acidic to enable partial and reversible pH-dependent ionization.(16−20) Mitochondrial uncoupling has two major phenotypes of therapeutic relevance including increased nutrient oxidation to compensate for lack of efficiency in ATP production and decreasing superoxide production from the ETC. The ETC is a primary source of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in most tissues. ETC-derived superoxide formation occurs via a nonenzymatic process when single electrons on coenzymes or prosthetic groups in redox centers interact with molecular oxygen.(21) Single electrons in the ETC only transiently exist in redox centers, and the dwell time for single electrons in an unstable state increases the likelihood of superoxide production. Mitochondrial uncouplers decrease mitochondrial superoxide production by stimulating faster electron transfer that decreases the dwell time for single electrons in the ETC.(21)
    The therapeutic potential of mitochondrial uncouplers is related to their dual roles in increasing nutrient oxidation and decreasing ROS production from the ETC. On the one hand, increased nutrient oxidation promotes leanness and is a therapeutic strategy to treat obesity and related metabolic diseases.(22−29) On the other hand, mitochondrial ROS are linked to numerous pathologies including ischemia–reperfusion injury, inflammation, insulin resistance, neurodegeneration, and many other pathologies. Importantly, mitochondrial uncouplers prevent ROS production, which is advantageous compared to antioxidants that scavenge ROS that have already been produced. As such, decreasing mitochondrial ROS production has significant therapeutic potential with advantages over antioxidant scavengers.(30−32)Table 1 lists the most common small molecule mitochondrial uncouplers and their chemical properties.
    Table 1. Reported Mitochondrial Uncouplers
    a

    cLogP values calculated with ChemDraw Professional 16.0. N/A: not applicable. NR: not reported.

    b

    Minimum effective concentration determined polarographically using oxygen electrode apparatus, unless indicated by the following: ∗, TMRE staining. ∧, manometric measurement; +, Seahorse XF flux analysis.

    Prototype Uncouplers DNP and FCCP

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Therapeutic uncoupling has been demonstrated in humans treated with DNP. DNP was used in the preparation of munitions during World War I, and workers in munitions factories in direct contact with DNP experienced significant weight loss and sometimes death.(33) DNP gained popularity as a weight loss drug in the early 1930s; after Stanford University clinician Maurice Tainter showed efficacy as a weight loss drug in obese humans.(34,35) DNP was reported to induce weight loss of ∼1.5 kg/week by increasing basal metabolic rate by 11% for every 100 mg taken.(36) By 1938, DNP had been used by 100 000 people and significant serious side effects were observed including damage to the liver, skeletal muscle, heart, and eyes, and some patients developed malignant hyperthermia resulting in death.(37−43) In 1938, Congress passed the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act that enabled the FDA to require proof of safety, and shortly thereafter, DNP was banned for use in humans.(44) In recent years, there has been a resurgence in DNP use by body builders and athletes.(45) There have been at least 62 published deaths from DNP poisoning, of which 10 have occurred since 2001.(36)
    Despite the history of toxicity with DNP, the medical research community has continued to explore the therapeutic potential of DNP in animals under well-controlled conditions. Caldeira da Silva et al. and Goldgof et al. both found that when treated with DNP, mice fed a high fat diet (HFD) showed improved metabolic parameters including reduced body weight, improved glucose tolerance, decreased blood insulin, and decreased serum or liver triglyceride levels compared to control mice.(23,46) Caldeira da Silva et al. demonstrated that low dose DNP intake (∼100 μg kg–1 day–1) in drinking water decreased oxidative damage associated with aging and extended lifespan by 7%,(46) a similar extension of lifespan has been observed in mice fed calorie-restricted diets.(47)
    DNP has a narrow therapeutic window between efficacy and toxicity; however, it is unclear whether the adverse effects are related to its on-target mitochondrial protonophore effects or its off-target effects on other organelles including depolarization of the plasma membrane. To harness the therapeutic potential of DNP by reducing its toxicity, DNP derivatives have been developed. For example, Blaikie et al. tethered DNP to triphenylphosphonium (TPP) (2, MitoDNP) to selectively target the mitochondria.(48) The dispersed positive charge in TPP conferred selective targeting to mitochondria; however, this alteration prevented 2 from leaving the mitochondria, and therefore, it lacked the capacity to transport additional protons.(48) To circumvent this problem, Chalmers and co-workers modified 2 by inserting a photocleavable linker between DNP and the TPP moiety, creating 3 (MitoPhotoDNP).(49) As the TPP moiety delivers DNP to the mitochondria, irradiation with 355 nm UV releases bioactive DNP.(49) Using the mitochondrial membrane potential-sensitive dye tetramethylrhodamine ethyl ester (TMRE), compound 3 was shown to be active at concentrations as low as 0.2 μM and lacked cytotoxicity up to 5 μM.(49) Unfortunately, UV irradiation of target organs is not viable as a therapeutic approach.
    Alternative strategies to dampen toxicity are to develop prodrugs that target DNP to specific organs of interest or formulate slow-release drugs that have a lower peak plasma concentration. To this end, Rachel Perry and colleagues developed a liver-targeted methyl ether derivative of DNP, 4 (DNPME), and a slow-release formulation named controlled-release mitochondrial protonophore (CRMP). Both molecules had an improved safety profile compared to DNP, decreased fat storage in liver, and improved insulin sensitivity. CRMP facilitates a wide therapeutic window by using a polymer coating system through which DNP diffuses over time. This results in sustained systemic release and a lower peak plasma concentration of DNP. CRMP had efficacy in rats up to 100 mg/kg without obvious toxicity, while DNP shows toxicity at 1 mg/kg. CRMP has an LD50 of ∼450 mg/kg, more than a 10-fold increase over DNP (∼45 mg/kg). Interestingly, the minimum dose required to lower hepatic triglyceride content (0.5 mg/kg) is 10-fold lower than that required for DNP (5 mg/kg). CRMP treatment (1 mg/kg) was shown to improve glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity and reduce ectopic lipid storage in HFD-fed Zucker diabetic fatty (ZDF) rats. CRMP also reversed hepatic steatosis in a rat model of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease without systemic toxicity.(27) No change in body fat mass was observed with CRMP treatment (1 mg/kg). Nonetheless, high doses of CRMP (>50 mg/kg) increased body temperature, demonstrating that while this formulation markedly decreases the risk of DNP-associated hyperthermia, DNP still retains its signature toxic effects with overdose.
    Tissue-targeted delivery of mitochondrial uncouplers offers a promising strategy to decrease off-target toxicity. For example, a liver-targeted prodrug of DNP, 4 (DNPME),(25) has no uncoupling activity until P450-mediated demethylation produces DNP in the liver. This prodrug was shown to have reduced toxicity with a ∼10-fold higher single dose LD50 (∼350 mg/kg) than DNP.(25) Its efficacy was demonstrated in both a HFD-fed rat model of T2D (using STZ-nicotinamide-treated rats as well as ZDF rats) and a rat of model of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). In both cases, 4 was demonstrated to improve insulin sensitivity, increase glucose tolerance, and decrease liver fat storage without altering white fat or inducing hyperthermia or systemic toxicities.(25)
    Interest in the therapeutic potential of DNP has recently expanded beyond obesity and metabolic disease. For example, research into its capacity to treat spinal cord injury and neurodegenerative diseases has gained attention.(50,51) This is because excitotoxicity and physical trauma have both been shown to lead to mitochondrial dysfunction,(30,31) which includes increased ROS production and extensive Ca2+ mitochondrial sequestration. The ability of DNP to decrease mitochondrial ROS production in multiple tissues including the brain has been well documented.(31,51−55) These properties highlight the potential of mitochondrial uncoupling as a treatment for multiple disorders associated with mitochondrial dysfunction.
    Another mitochondrial uncoupler that has been extensively studied is the hydrazone 5 (carbonyl cyanide p-(trifluoromethoxy)hydrazine, FCCP). Its development and discovery were first reported by Heytler et al. in 1962, along with its analogues such as 20 (carbonyl cyanide m-chlorophenylhydrazone, CCCP, Figure 2).(56)5 and 20 have uncoupling activity in mitochondria(56,57) and chloroplasts,(56−59) with 5 proving to be the more potent uncoupler (EC50 = 0.04 μM vs 0.1 μM, respectively).(60) Similar to DNP, 5 has a narrow therapeutic window and off-target effects(61−65) such as depolarization of the plasma membrane, thereby severely limiting its use in vivo. Because 5 is much more potent than DNP, its therapeutic window is more difficult to find for in vivo studies. Nevertheless, 5 serves as a valuable chemical probe for the assessment of bioenergetic function in isolated mitochondria and cultured cells, and it has been used to study neurodegenerative diseases.(31,62,65−76)

    Repurposing FDA-Approved Drugs

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Repurposing FDA-approved drugs with new indications is an attractive strategy for drug discovery. This strategy has been employed with varying degrees of success in the sphere of mitochondrial uncoupling. For example, some anesthetics are known to influence oxidative phosphorylation. Their disruption of ATP synthesis, dysregulation of electron and Ca2+ transport, and mitochondrial uncoupling activity have been reported.(77) In particular, 6 (bupivacaine) is a local anesthetic that is a validated mitochondrial protonophore,(78) which was confirmed by mitochondrial swelling in the presence of valinomycin and potassium acetate.(79,80) The mitochondrial uncoupling activity of 6 is hypothesized to arise from its liposolubility and pKa (8.1) that allow it to passively transfer between the inner-membrane space and matrix. However, Terada et al. and van Dam et al. discovered(81,82) that the protonophoric mitochondrial uncoupling of 6 occurs only in the presence of hydrophobic anions such as picrate; otherwise, it acts as a decoupler by inducing a slip in the proton pumps during oxidative phosphorylation. Sztark et al. later showed(83) that the uncoupling or decoupling activity of 6 is dependent on the respiration state of the mitochondria and the membrane potential.
    Unfortunately, 6 has been shown to be myotoxic, neurotoxic,(84−88) and cardiotoxic.(89) Weinberg and co-workers found that the myotoxicity of 6 is in part due to the inhibition of carnitine metabolism in cardiac mitochondria.(90) Lirk et al. established(87) that the neurotoxicity of 6 is linked to ROS-mediated activation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway.(91) Furthermore, 6 has been shown to promote ROS generation,(92) which is thought to contribute to its toxicity. Although the exact mechanism of the enhanced ROS generation is unclear, disruption of the ETC via reversible binding to complexes I and III plays a role. 6-induced cardiotoxicity in rats could be reversed with lipid infusion using Intralipid.(93) More recently, Chen and co-workers showed that a lipid emulsion version of 6 helped to minimize myocardial toxicity;(89) however, as it stands, significant toxicity of 6 is prohibitive against its use beyond local anesthesia.
    In contrast, a drug that does show promise for expanded therapeutic use is 7 (niclosamide ethanolamine, NEN), the salt form of niclosamide, an approved anthelmintic drug. 7 is a Wnt and STAT3 inhibitor that also has mitochondrial uncoupling activity. One of the proposed modes of action is that it uncouples the mitochondria of parasitic worms, thereby inhibiting ATP production.(94) It is orally bioavailable and has an excellent safety profile.(95,96) Oxygen electrode studies show that 7 uncouples mitochondrial respiration in isolated mitochondria (from rat liver) and also mouse embryonic fibroblast (NIH-3T3) cells at concentrations as low as 1 μM. When tested in vivo, ∼150 mg kg–1 day–1 dose was found to prevent and reverse hyperglycemia, hyperinsulinemia, hepatic steatosis, and also decrease weight gain in HFD fed C57BL/6 mice when compared to control mice.(28) In addition, 7 treatment delayed disease progression in a db/db mouse model of diabetes.(28) The effect of 7 on whole body glucose metabolism was later partially attributed to its acute inhibition of glucagon-mediated signaling through β-catenin.(97)

    Repurposed Chemicals

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The therapeutic potential of DNP was initially identified as a consequence of the unintended weight loss experienced by workers handling and inhaling DNP. Similarly, other mitochondrial uncouplers have been discovered by chance. For example, 8 (TTFB) was part of a benzimidazole library intended for herbicidal use.(98) Jones and Watson(99) and Büchel et al.(100) concurrently reported 8’s mitochondrial uncoupling activity. Jones and Watson, using a Warburg apparatus, and Buchel et al., using an oxygen electrode, showed that 0.03–0.08 μM 8 was necessary to elicit uncoupling activity. The observed uncoupling activity was attributed to the compound’s pKa (NH) of 5.04–5.6,(98−100) suggesting that 8 is active in its anionic form, which is stabilized by the aromatic imidazole ring.(101,102) However, due to mammalian toxicity(98) and an uncoupling preference for brain mitochondria over liver mitochondria,(103)8 has not been pursued as a therapy for metabolic or neurodegenerative diseases.
    Developed from the fluorescent dye rhodamine 19,(104)9 (C4R1) is a mitochondrial uncoupler (EC50 of ∼1 μM) that increased mitochondrial respiration with a narrow peak maximum respiration at ∼15 μM.(105) This uncoupling activity may be attributed to its pKa of 7.3.(104) Studies found that 9 is a cationic protonophore that is selective for mitochondria whose activity is dependent on membrane potential.(104,105)9 is orally bioavailable and offers neuroprotection by reducing brain swelling and cognitive decline in a stroke model.(24,105) In addition, it was investigated as a potential obesity treatment in HFD-fed C57BL/6 mice.(24) Initially administered at 30 μmol kg–1 day–1, dose de-escalation was required twice during the study as 9 proved to be severely anorectic at the higher tested doses. Body weight and total fat mass decreased by 19% and 20%, respectively. However, unwanted reduction of lean body mass was also observed.(24) Indirect calorimetry demonstrated an increase in energy expenditure, as expected, which may partially account for the fat loss together with the reduction in food intake.
    10 (ellipticine) is an alkaloid isolated from the plant Ochrosia elliptica.10 is a topoisomerase II-β inhibitor that also has mitochondrial uncoupling activity.(106)10 increases mitochondrial respiration and depolarizes the mitochondrial membrane in both plant and mammalian cells at concentrations as low as 0.1 μM.(107−109) However, concentrations above 50 μM were found to inhibit mitochondrial respiration.(108,110) Cationic (pKa = 7.4) and neutral forms of 10 are implicated in its mitochondrial uncoupling activity, and its membrane permeability was demonstrated to be pH independent.(109,111,112) Unfortunately, 10 is cytotoxic, inducing endoplasmic reticulum stress.(113) As such, there are no current reports of 10 as a chemical probe for mitochondrial function.
    The salicylanilide 11 (S13)(114) increases mitochondrial respiration at concentrations as low as 0.032 μM.(115) Its anionic form (pKa = 5.8) is suggested to be the active form during mitochondrial uncoupling activity.(116) It is proposed that in its anionic state, 11 forms an internal six-membered ring, which retains the neutral state’s lipophilicity, permitting passive diffusion through the mitochondrial membrane.(115) However, 11 inhibits mitochondrial respiration above 0.10 μM.(117) The toxicity of 11 prevents its use as a therapeutic.
    Originally synthesized for agricultural fungicidal and acaricidal usage,(118)12 (tyrphostin A9/SF-6847) is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor(119,120) with protonophoric uncoupling activity, increasing mitochondrial respiration at concentrations as low as 0.02 μM.(121,122) Its anionic state (pKa = 6.7) is hypothesized as the active structure during the uncoupling process.(122) NMR studies and energy barrier calculations indicate that a restricted rotational barrier localizes the negative charge, which is also shielded by the two tert-butyl moieties on the benzene ring, allowing 12 to retain its lipophilicity when deprotonated.(123−125) The therapeutic potential of 12 has only been partially explored due to its cytotoxicity. 12 has reported cytotoxicity above 0.20 μM,(125) hepatotoxicity above 0.97 μM,(125) and a mouse LD50 of 29 mg/kg.(118) Nonetheless, low concentrations (∼0.5 μM) have been shown to be protective against glutamate-induced oxidative damage in neuronal cells.(126) Additionally, 12 suppresses insulin-induced fatty acid synthesis in rat adipocytes. However, as this effect occurred at a concentration higher than the range within which 12 causes mitochondrial uncoupling, it was proposed to be a consequence of alterations in membrane conditions, potentially independent from its uncoupling activity.(127)

    Chemical Library Screens for Drug Discovery

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Screening of chemical libraries has enabled the identification of numerous mitochondrial uncouplers. For example, a library screen for anticancer activity led to the discovery of the 1,3-bis(dichlorophenyl)urea 13 (SR4).(128) Treatment of HL-60 leukemia cells with 13 resulted in mitochondria-induced apoptosis, which was associated with a depolarization of the mitochondrial membrane.(128) Further investigation using in vivo and in vitro cancer models revealed that 13 activates AMP-activated kinase (AMPK) by promoting phosphorylation and induction of antitumor mechanisms.(129) As activation of the AMPK pathway has beneficial effects on metabolic disturbances including obesity and T2D, 13 was investigated for its effect on HFD-induced obese C57BL/6 mice.(130) Mice dosed with 5 mg/kg three times a week experienced a 16% reduction in body weight and ∼35% reduction in body fat mass.(22) Treatment with 13 also improved insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism, as well as decreased hepatic lipid content, which is suggested to be a consequence of AMPK activation(22) and mitochondrial uncoupling activity.(131) By use of Seahorse XF flux analysis, 13 has been shown to increase respiration of isolated mitochondria at concentrations as low as 3 μM and up to 25 μM, independent of the ANT and UCPs. 13 induces swelling in valinomycin-treated mitochondria in a potassium acetate buffer, indicating protonophoric uncoupling activity.(131) However, selectivity for mitochondria has not been established, and efficacy is limited by liver toxicity.(131)
    Discovered from a natural product library screen, 14 (Ppc-1) is a secondary metabolite of the slime mold Polysphondylium pseudo-candidum.(132) Kikuchi and co-workers discovered(133) that this molecule has mitochondrial uncoupling activity in mouse liver mitochondria, polarographically increasing oxygen consumption between 10 and 20 μM without causing toxicity or inhibiting mitochondrial respiration.(134) It is currently unclear how 14 functions as a mitochondrial uncoupler, but studies have established that its mitochondrial uncoupling activity is not due to the formation of a permeability transition pore (PTP), which facilitates ion permeability into the mitochondrial matrix.(26,135)
    14 suppressed weight gain in ICR mice when administered at 0.8 mg/kg/week by intraperitoneal injection over an 8-week period.(26) The effective range of 14 was found to be very narrow with treatment at higher (≥4 mg kg–1 week–1) and lower doses (0.16 mg kg–1 week–1) both proving ineffective at suppressing weight gain. Analysis of serum samples revealed elevated fatty acid levels. Similarly, 3T3-L1 adipocytes treated with 14 released fatty acids into their cell culture medium. The mechanism underlying this fatty acid release remains to be determined. Despite the apparent narrow effective range, there is still scope to evaluate the effects of 14 on HFD-induced obese mice.
    In a small molecule library screen for inhibitors of tobacco pollen germination and growth, 15 (Endosidin9, ES9)(136) was found to also inhibit clathrin-mediated endocytosis (CME) with an IC50 of 5 μM.(137) Because CME is dependent on ATP stores, the impact of 15 on ATP production was assessed, revealing mitochondrial uncoupling activity.(137)15 increased mitochondrial respiration at concentrations as low as 1 μM (137) but depleted ATP stores above 10 μM, which was attributed to depolarization of the plasma membrane.(137) Dejonghe et al. discovered that 15 inhibits CME via cellular acidification through mitochondrial uncoupling and depolarization of the plasma membrane.(137)15 has yet to be explored as a chemical probe for mitochondrial function; however, there is evidence for its use in this arena.
    Discovered from a high-throughput screen, 16 (CZ5) is a protonophoric mitochondrial uncoupler(138) that has been shown by Clark-type oxygen electrode to increase mitochondrial respiration in a dose-dependent manner. 16 promoted uncoupled respiration in a cell-type-specific manner.(138)16 has low cytotoxicity up to 10 μM, but higher concentrations were required to increase mitochondrial respiration in hepatocytes.(138) In addition, 16 increased the ratio of reduced:oxidized glutathione in adipocytes, indicating improved antioxidant defense.
    16 has favorable pharmacokinetics for in vivo use and is orally bioavailable (58%). In addition, a single dose of 500 mg/kg was administered without acute toxicity.(138) Obese mice orally dosed with 10 mg kg–1 day–1 over a 5-week period resulted in suppressed food intake, reduced body weight, and reduced total fat mass in comparison to control mice.(138) Improved metabolic parameters were also observed including reduced plasma cholesterol and reduced plasma and muscle triacylglycerols, as well as decreased fasting blood glucose levels and decreased insulin levels.(138) Hepatic triacylglycerol levels were not significantly altered in this mouse model, supporting the suggestion of cell-type selectivity identified in cell culture experiments. The adipose tissue uncoupling activity of 16 makes it an attractive candidate for further investigation for treatment of obesity and associated metabolic diseases.
    Discovered from a diversity chemical library,(139)17 (BAM15) was found to have mitochondrial uncoupling activity with an EC50 of 0.27 μM in L6 myoblasts as determined via a Seahorse XF flux analyzer.(140) The activity of 17 suggested selectivity for mitochondria over the plasma membrane, which was confirmed by electrophysiology studies.(139)17 was validated as a protonophoric uncoupler by a valinomycin and potassium acetate mitochondrial swelling assay. Kenwood et al. hypothesized(139) that the selectivity for mitochondria was due to the molecule’s pKa (7.5). Structure–activity relationship (SAR) studies established that the furazan and pyrazine rings were essential for its uncoupling activity.(140)17 is capable of uncoupling mitochondria over a wide concentration range (0.1–50 μM) in hepatocytes, myoblasts, cardiomyocytes, and fibroblasts indicating that it does not have cell-type specificity.(139) More recent studies have established the utility of 17 for the study of basic mitochondrial function, particularly due to its lack of confounding off-target effects and its broad range of efficacy without toxicity.(141−143,139)17 was shown to be bioactive in vivo where it prevented renal damage caused by ischemia–reperfusion.(139) The efficacy of 17 in treating obesity and metabolic disease remains to be investigated.

    Synergistic Drug Delivery To Increase Uncoupling Potential

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Because cationic TPP ions accumulate in the mitochondria,(144−150) they are commonly used as a handle(48) for mitochondrial drug delivery. Severin et al. and Sukhanova et al. discovered(151) that 18 (C12TPP) in the presence of the fatty acid palmitate can induce mild mitochondrial uncoupling in rat-heart mitochondria and decrease mitochondrial H2O2 production.(151,152) In the absence of fatty acid additives, 18 can uncouple yeast mitochondria at concentrations as low as ∼5.5 μM, but this is likely to occur due to the presence of endogenous fatty acids in the yeast cells.(152,153) Although 18 lacks pro-oxidant activity at high concentrations,(151,152) it does inhibit mitochondrial respiration above 40 μM, a consequence of mitochondrial swelling induced by detergent behavior.(152)
    Coadministration of 18 with either 5 or DNP reduced the concentration of uncoupler needed to increase mitochondrial respiration (0.4 μM vs 0.6 μM and 10 μM vs 55 μM, respectively).(154) It is hypothesized that 18 interacts with the anionic forms of 5 and DNP to facilitate mitochondrial localization, minimizing off-target depolarization of the plasma membrane. The effect of coadministration of 18 and generality of the approach with another uncoupler has yet to be tested in vivo. However, dosing mice fed a HFD with 50 μmol kg–1 day–1 C12TPP for 16 days was found to suppress appetite and decrease body weight (∼12% loss) and fat mass (∼24% loss) without noticeable toxicity.(155) Brown adipose tissue (BAT) was suggested to play a role in the activity of 18 as the total mitochondrial and UCP1 content was increased in BAT while the mitochondrial protein content was not altered in skeletal muscle of treated mice. Intriguingly, these results are contrary to the finding that DNP-mediated uncoupling reduces UCP1 expression and BAT activity.(23) Furthermore, the activity of 18 in brown adipocytes and isolated mitochondria was found to be UCP1-independent; therefore, the effect of 18 on BAT remains undefined.
    In addition to 2, 3, and 18, numerous other TPP mitochondrial uncouplers have been reported, some of which have shown success in vitro and in vivo including 19 (MitoQ10).(156) Of the TPP uncouplers reported, the best characterized is 19.(157) Initially designed as a method for delivering ubiquinone to the mitochondria for antioxidant purposes,(156)19 was found to have mitochondrial uncoupling properties, promoting mitochondrial respiration at concentrations as low as 2.5 μM via the ANT;(158) concentrations above 10 μM led to decreased membrane potential and cell death.(156) However, later studies discovered that 19 has nanomolar uncoupling activity, although exact concentrations were not specified. 19 displays antioxidant properties in addition to mitochondrial uncoupling activity, as it was able to prevent H2O2 oxidation of the fatty acid cis-parinaric acid.(156)19’s therapeutic use has been explored in vivo;(159,160) however, these studies focused on its activity as an antioxidant rather than as a mitochondrial uncoupler.

    Natural Product Isolates

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As demonstrated with 14, natural product isolation has resulted in the discovery of several mitochondrial uncouplers. 20 ((+)-usnic acid) is a secondary metabolite of numerous lichens including Usnea articulata that possesses mitochondrial uncoupling activity.(161) Abo-Khatwa et al. demonstrated polarographically that 20 could stimulate respiration at concentrations as low as 0.75 μM in mouse-liver mitochondria.(161) This observed uncoupling activity can be attributed to the compound’s reported pKa of 4.4, which suggests that the molecule is active in its anionic form.(162) Unfortunately, this molecule has a narrow therapeutic window, as studies have demonstrated that concentrations above 1 μM inhibit mitochondrial respiration, which is suggested to be a consequence of 20 altering the function of the ETC.(161,163) Mouse and rat studies found that this molecule causes hepatotoxicity.(164,165) Due to observed hepatotoxicity in mice and rats, 20 is not an ideal therapeutic candidate for metabolic or neurodegenerative diseases.(164,165) Nevertheless, 20 is currently found in numerous unregulated weight-loss supplements with reported hepatotoxicity including the dietary supplement LipoKinetix.(166−168)
    Isolated from the hexane extract of the plant Verbesina persicifolia,21 (4β-cinnamoyloxy,1β,3α-dihydroxyeudesm-7,8-ene, CDE) is a mitochondrial uncoupler that increases mitochondrial respiration at concentrations as low as 20 μM and as high as 100 μM, as measured by a Clark electrode.(169)21’s exact uncoupling activity is unclear, but mitochondrial swelling experiments with potassium acetate and 21 suggest protonophoric activity. Oxygen consumption studies found that 21’s mitochondrial uncoupling activity was abolished in the presence of ketocholestanol, suggesting that the molecule’s uncoupling mechanism of action is linked to the membrane protein cytochrome c oxygenase.(169) Although this molecule is commonly used in Mexican folk medicine,(169) it has yet to be tested in vivo as an isolate for its therapeutic benefits.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    There is sufficient evidence in rodents that small molecule mitochondrial uncouplers have therapeutic utility for numerous diseases, but the main barrier to clinical translation is safety. Current efforts to improve safety center on improving mitochondrial selectivity to avoid off-target actions on other organelles, developing molecules with self-limiting properties such that they only partially depolarize mitochondria and restricting activity to specific tissues of interest. Some of these issues can be mitigated through tissue-targeting scaffolds, prodrug strategies, and formulation chemistry. While a myriad of small molecules have been reported as mitochondrial uncouplers, a small number of chemical properties that serve as guidelines as uncouplers have emerged: the pKa of ionizable protons and lipophilicity. Early mitochondrial uncouplers emphasize the importance of compound acidity (pKa), as many of the early reported uncouplers such as DNP and 5 have pKa values below 6.8. However, the toxicity of these compounds has fostered a general reluctance to use and develop mitochondrial uncouplers as therapeutics. In contrast, recently reported mitochondrial uncouplers with pKa values within the range of 6.8–8.1 including 9 and 17 demonstrate an emerging shift toward the development of more weakly acidic uncouplers. The expectation is that the higher pKa will confer self-limiting properties in mitochondria and mitigate off-target effects on nonmitochondrial organelles that have a lower pH.
    Organ selectivity is a further consideration that may enhance the efficacy of uncouplers. Targeting uncoupling to white adipose tissue and/or the liver may enhance the desirable metabolic effects of uncoupling while attenuating toxicity in other tissues. Recent investigations including prodrug development such as 4 and the adipocyte selective activity of 16 demonstrate the potential of this line of development. Further, greater emphasis has been placed on the development of uncouplers that are selective for the mitochondria versus other cellular compartments as exemplified by 3, 17, and 18. Future mitochondrial uncouplers will need to be developed with pKa and lipophilicity in consideration to aid in mitochondrial selectivity while still maintaining drug-like properties.
    In summary, small molecule mitochondrial uncouplers appear to have therapeutic potential for treating a myriad of diseases; however, clinical development has been hindered in part due to the well-known toxicity of DNP. It has been almost 80 years since DNP was banned for use in humans, but new research is beginning to overturn the misconception that all mitochondrial uncouplers will cause toxicity. Future work to hone pKa, lipophilicity, tissue distribution, and mitochondrial localization will certainly result in lower toxicity and aid in the development of new mitochondrial uncoupler clinical candidates with improved safety profiles.

      1
      Chemiosmotic coupling in oxidative and photosynthetic phosphorylation
      Mitchell, Peter
      Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, Bioenergetics (2011), 1807 (12), 1507-1538CODEN: BBBEB4; ISSN:0005-2728. (Elsevier B. V.)
      50 years ago Peter Mitchell proposed the chemiosmotic hypothesis for which he was awarded the Nobel Prize for Chem. in 1978. His comprehensive review on chemiosmotic coupling known as the first "Gray Book", has been reprinted here with permission, to offer an electronic record and easy access to this important contribution to the biochem. literature. This remarkable account of Peter Mitchell's ideas originally published in 1966 is a landmark and must-read publication for any scientist in the field of bioenergetics. As far as was possible, the wording and format of the original publication have been retained. Some changes were required for consistency with BBA formats though these do not affect scientific meaning. A scanned version of the original publication is also provided as a downloadable file in Supplementary Information and can be found online at doi:10.1016/j.bbabio.2011.09.018. See also Editorial in this issue by Peter R. Rich. Original title: CHEMIOSMOTIC COUPLING IN OXIDATIVE AND PHOTOSYNTHETIC PHOSPHORYLATION, by Peter Mitchell, Glynn Research Labs., Bodmin, Cornwall, England.

      Weinbach, E. C.; Garbus, J. Mechanism of action of reagents that uncouple oxidative phosphorylation. Nature 1969, 221, 1016– 1018,  DOI: 10.1038/2211016a0
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Mechanism of action of reagents that uncouple oxidative phosphorylation
      Weinbach, Eugene C.; Garbus, Joel
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1969), 221 (5185), 1016-18CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
      The mechanism of action of reagents that uncouple oxidative phosphorylation is discussed and the following sequence of events in the uncoupling is proposed to account for the observations and arguments cited herein. Uncoupling reagents in the unionized state traverse the lipid envelope or the lipid-protein interface of the mitochondrial membrane. Inside the mitochondrion the reagent ionizes and interacts with the charged groups of the protein, presumably ε-amino groups, which leads to reorganization of the protein structure. These conformational transitions could result in a structural disorganization and altered function of the enzymes catalyzing the coupling of phosphorylation to electron transport.

      6
      The regulation and physiology of mitochondrial proton leak
      Divakaruni, Ajit S.; Brand, Martin D.
      Physiology (2011), 26 (June), 192-205CODEN: PHYSCI; ISSN:1548-9213. (International Union of Physiological Sciences)
      A review. Mitochondria couple respiration to ATP synthesis through an electrochem. proton gradient. Proton leak across the inner membrane allows adjustment of the coupling efficiency. The aim of this review is threefold: (1) introduce the unfamiliar reader to proton leak and its physiol. significance, (2) review the role and regulation of uncoupling proteins, and (3) outline the prospects of proton leak as an avenue to treat obesity, diabetes, and age-related disease.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXpt1ymt7c%253D&md5=00f5ce4dc877842cb759585f3fdb2836
    7. 7
      Mailloux, R. J.; Harper, M.-E. Uncoupling proteins and the control of mitochondrial reactive oxygen species production. Free Radical Biol. Med. 2011, 51, 1106– 1115,  DOI: 10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2011.06.022
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Uncoupling proteins and the control of mitochondrial reactive oxygen species production
      Mailloux, Ryan J.; Harper, Mary-Ellen
      Free Radical Biology & Medicine (2011), 51 (6), 1106-1115CODEN: FRBMEH; ISSN:0891-5849. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Reactive oxygen species (ROS), natural byproducts of aerobic respiration, are important cell signaling mols., which left unchecked can severely impair cellular functions and induce cell death. Hence, cells have developed a series of systems to keep ROS in the nontoxic range. Uncoupling proteins (UCPs) 1-3 are mitochondrial anion carrier proteins that are purported to play important roles in minimizing ROS emission from the electron transport chain. The function of UCP1 in this regard is highly contentious. However, UCPs 2 and 3 are generally thought to be activated by ROS or ROS byproducts to induce proton leak, thus providing a neg. feedback loop for mitochondrial ROS prodn. In our lab., we have not only confirmed that ROS activate UCP2 and UCP3, but also demonstrated that UCP2 and UCP3 are controlled by covalent modification by glutathione. Furthermore, the reversible glutathionylation is required to activate/inhibit UCP2 and UCP3, but not UCP1. Hence, our findings are consistent with the notion that UCPs 2 and 3 are acutely activated by ROS, which then directly modulate the glutathionylation status of the UCP to decrease ROS emission and participate in cell signaling mechanisms.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtVagtrnM&md5=546679801413f39aa6b44b22255b1d1d
    8. 8
      Erlanson-Albertsson, C. The role of uncoupling proteins in the regulation of metabolism. Acta Physiol. Scand. 2003, 178, 405– 412,  DOI: 10.1046/j.1365-201X.2003.01159.x
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      The role of uncoupling proteins in the regulation of metabolism
      Erlanson-Albertsson, C.
      Acta Physiologica Scandinavica (2003), 178 (4), 405-412CODEN: APSCAX; ISSN:0001-6772. (Blackwell Publishing Ltd.)
      A review and discussion. Investigations of variations in metabolic efficiency and thermogenesis have a short and turbulent history. In small animals, non-shivering thermogenesis and diet-induced thermogenesis have a great impact on overall body wt., and the question is whether mechanisms to waste energy have evolved also in human energy metab. The candidate mols. for this adaptive thermogenesis are the uncoupling proteins. This is a newly discovered family of proteins, consisting of at least 5 proteins, namely UCP1, UCP2, UCP3, UCP4, and UCP5. Although a role for UCP1 in thermogenesis is unequivocal, the physiol. function of the newer uncoupling proteins is as yet unclear. UCP1 is present in brown adipose tissue and has a well-documented role in cold-induced thermogenesis. The targeted disruption of the UCP1-gene rendered animals that were cold-sensitive, but not obese. UCP2 mRNA has a ubiquitous distribution in tissue, namely, in skeletal muscle, white and brown adipose tissue, the gastrointestinal tract, the lung, and the spleen. By targeting the UCP2-gene there was no effect on whole body energy metab., but instead, a reduced ability to protect against free-radical O species. UCP2 has also been shown to act as a neg. regulator for insulin secretion. UCP3 is present in skeletal muscle. Targeted disruption of the UCP3-gene gave no effect on whole body energy metab., but showed the mitochondria in muscle to be more coupled. Thus, the uncoupling proteins may be important in various specific ways, as protectors of free radical O species and as regulators of ATP-dependent processes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXmt1Crt7s%253D&md5=3177c257bf12f55e7d7a6bc5a70a455c
    9. 9
      Brand, M. D.; Esteves, T. C. Physiological functions of the mitochondrial uncoupling proteins ucp2 and ucp3. Cell Metab. 2005, 2, 85– 93,  DOI: 10.1016/j.cmet.2005.06.002
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Physiological functions of the mitochondrial uncoupling proteins UCP2 and UCP3
      Brand, Martin D.; Esteves, Telma C.
      Cell Metabolism (2005), 2 (2), 85-93CODEN: CMEEB5; ISSN:1550-4131. (Cell Press)
      A review. Evidence for the physiol. functions of UCP2 and UCP3 is critically reviewed. They do not mediate adaptive thermogenesis, but they may be significantly thermogenic under specific pharmacol. conditions. There is strong evidence that the mild regulated uncoupling they cause attenuates mitochondrial reactive oxygen species prodn., protects against cellular damage, and diminishes insulin secretion. Evidence that they export fatty acids physiol. is weak. UCP2 and UCP3 are important potential targets for treatment of aging, degenerative diseases, diabetes, and perhaps obesity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXps12ht70%253D&md5=7f52dd27a7da3e3b377cf779ad8915fd

      Ost, M.; Keipert, S.; Klaus, S. Targeted mitochondrial uncoupling beyond UCP1 – the fine line between death and metabolic health. Biochimie 2017, 134, 77– 85,  DOI: 10.1016/j.biochi.2016.11.013

    11. 11
      Rousset, S.; Alves-Guerra, M.; Mozo, J.; Miroux, B.; Cassard-Doulcier, A.; Bouillaud, F.; Ricquier, D. The biology of mitochondrial uncoupling proteins. Diabetes 2004, 53, S130– S135,  DOI: 10.2337/diabetes.53.2007.S130
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      The biology of mitochondrial uncoupling proteins
      Rousset, Sophie; Alves-Guerra, Marie-Clotilde; Mozo, Julien; Miroux, Bruno; Cassard-Doulcier, Anne-Marie; Bouillaud, Frederic; Ricquier, Daniel
      Diabetes (2004), 53 (Suppl. 1), S130-S135CODEN: DIAEAZ; ISSN:0012-1797. (American Diabetes Association)
      A review. Uncoupling proteins (UCPs) are mitochondrial transporters present in the inner membrane of mitochondria. They are found in all mammals and in plants. They belong to the family of anion mitochondrial carriers including adenine nucleotide transporters. The term "uncoupling protein" was originally used for UCP1, which is uniquely present in mitochondria of brown adipocytes, the thermogenic cells that maintain body temp. in small rodents. In these cells, UCP1 acts as a proton carrier activated by free fatty acids and creates a shunt between complexes of the respiratory chain and ATP synthase. Activation of UCP1 enhances respiration, and the uncoupling process results in a futile cycle and dissipation of oxidn. energy as heat. UCP2 is ubiquitous and highly expressed in the lymphoid system, macrophages, and pancreatic islets. UCP3 is mainly expressed in skeletal muscles. In comparison to the established uncoupling and thermogenic activities of UCP1, UCP2 and UCP3 appear to be involved in the limitation of free radical levels in cells rather than in physiol. uncoupling and thermogenesis. Moreover, UCP2 is a regulator of insulin secretion and UCP3 is involved in fatty acid metab.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhtlGqtr0%253D&md5=787d484b11ea68797284db7a5d05c0c0
    12. 12
      Busiello, R. A.; Savarese, S.; Lombardi, A. Mitochondrial uncoupling proteins and energy metabolism. Front. Physiol. 2015, 6, 36,  DOI: 10.3389/fphys.2015.00036
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Mitochondrial uncoupling proteins and energy metabolism
      Busiello Rosa A; Savarese Sabrina; Lombardi Assunta
      Frontiers in physiology (2015), 6 (), 36 ISSN:1664-042X.
      Understanding the metabolic factors that contribute to energy metabolism (EM) is critical for the development of new treatments for obesity and related diseases. Mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation is not perfectly coupled to ATP synthesis, and the process of proton-leak plays a crucial role. Proton-leak accounts for a significant part of the resting metabolic rate (RMR) and therefore enhancement of this process represents a potential target for obesity treatment. Since their discovery, uncoupling proteins have stimulated great interest due to their involvement in mitochondrial-inducible proton-leak. Despite the widely accepted uncoupling/thermogenic effect of uncoupling protein one (UCP1), which was the first in this family to be discovered, the reactions catalyzed by its homolog UCP3 and the physiological role remain under debate. This review provides an overview of the role played by UCP1 and UCP3 in mitochondrial uncoupling/functionality as well as EM and suggests that they are a potential therapeutic target for treating obesity and its related diseases such as type II diabetes mellitus.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2MroslWksA%253D%253D&md5=2bfb50f0f0edd097f5b2a4bb149cd77f
    13. 13
      Ricquier, D.; Bouillaud, F. Mitochondrial uncoupling proteins: From mitochondria to the regulation of energy balance. J. Physiol. 2000, 529, 3– 10,  DOI: 10.1111/j.1469-7793.2000.00003.x
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      Mitochondrial uncoupling proteins: from mitochondria to the regulation of energy balance
      Ricquier, Daniel; Bouillaud, Frederic
      Journal of Physiology (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2000), 529 (1), 3-10CODEN: JPHYA7; ISSN:0022-3751. (Cambridge University Press)
      A review, with 40 refs. The coupling of oxygen consumption to ADP phosphorylation is incomplete, as is particularly evident in brown adipocyte mitochondria which use a regulated uncoupling mechanism to dissipate heat produced by substrate oxidn. In brown adipose tissue, uncoupling is effected by a specific protein in the inner mitochondrial membrane referred to as uncoupling protein-1 (UCP1). UCP1 gene disruption in mice has confirmed UCP1's role in cold-induced thermogenesis. Genetic anal. of human cohorts has suggested that UCP1 plays a minor role in the control of fat content and body wt. The recent cloning of UCP2 and UCP3, 2 homologs of UCP1, has boosted research on the importance of respiration control in metabolic processes, metabolic diseases and energy balance. UCP2 is widely expressed in different organs whereas UCP3 is mainly present in skeletal muscle. The chromosomal localization of UCP2 as well as UCP2 mRNA induction by a lipid-rich diet in obesity-resistant mice suggested that UCP2 is involved in diet-induced thermogenesis. A strong linkage between markers in the vicinity of human UCP2 and UCP3 (which are adjacent genes) and resting metabolic rate was calcd. UCPs are known or supposed to participate in basal and regulatory thermogenesis, but their exact biochem. and physiol. functions have yet to be elucidated. UCPs may constitute novel targets in the development of drugs designed to modulate substrate oxidn. However, very recent data suggest an important role for the UCPs in the control of prodn. of free radicals by mitochondria, and in response to oxidants.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXovVWqu7c%253D&md5=04e319b34c41613a5492393f71bdb16c
    14. 14
      Nedergaard, J.; Golozoubova, V.; Matthias, A.; Asadi, A.; Jacobsson, A.; Cannon, B. UCP1: The only protein able to mediate adaptive non-shivering thermogenesis and metabolic inefficiency. Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Bioenerg. 2001, 1504, 82– 106,  DOI: 10.1016/S0005-2728(00)00247-4
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14
      UCP1: the only protein able to mediate adaptive non-shivering thermogenesis and metabolic inefficiency
      Nedergaard, J.; Golozoubova, V.; Matthias, A.; Asadi, A.; Jacobsson, A.; Cannon, B.
      Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, Bioenergetics (2001), 1504 (1), 82-106CODEN: BBBEB4; ISSN:0005-2728. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review, with 161 refs. The uniqueness of UCP1 (as compared to UCP2/UCP3) is evident from expression anal. and ablation studies. UCP1 expression is pos. correlated with metabolic inefficiency, being increased by cold acclimation (in adults or perinatally) and overfeeding, and reduced in fasting and genetic obesity. Such a simple relationship is not observable for UCP2/UCP3. Studies with UCP1-ablated animals substantiate the unique role of UCP1: the phenomenon of adaptive adrenergic non-shivering thermogenesis in the intact animal is fully dependent on the presence of UCP1, and so is any kind of cold acclimation-recruited non-shivering thermogenesis; thus UCP2/UCP3 (or any other proteins or metabolic processes) cannot substitute for UCP1 physiol., irresp. of their demonstrated ability to show uncoupling in reconstituted systems or when ectopically expressed. Norepinephrine-induced thermogenesis in brown-fat cells is absolutely dependent on UCP1, as is the uncoupled state and the recoupling by purine nucleotides in isolated brown-fat mitochondria. Although very high UCP2/UCP3 mRNA levels are obsd. in brown adipose tissue of UCP1-ablated mice, there is no indication that the isolated brown-fat mitochondria are uncoupled; thus, high expression of UCP2/UCP3 does not necessarily confer to the mitochondria of a tissue a propensity for being innately uncoupled. Whereas the thermogenic effect of fatty acids in brown-fat cells is fully UCP1-dependent, this is not the case in brown-fat mitochondria; this adds complexity to the issues concerning the mechanisms of UCP1 function and the pathway from β3-adrenoceptor stimulation to UCP1 activation and thermogenesis. In addn. to amino acid sequences conserved in all UCPs as part of the tripartite structure, all UCPs contain certain residues assocd. with nucleotide binding. However, conserved amongst all UCP1s so far sequenced, and without parallel in all UCP2/UCP3, are two sequences: 144SHLHGIKP and the C-terminal sequence RQTVDC(A/T)T; these sequences may therefore be essential for the unique thermogenic function of UCP1. The level of UCP1 in the organism is basically regulated at the transcriptional level (physiol. probably mainly through the β3-adrenoceptor/CREB pathway), with influences from UCP1 mRNA stability and from the delay caused by translation. It is concluded that UCP1 is unique amongst the uncoupling proteins and is the only protein able to mediate adaptive non-shivering thermogenesis and the ensuing metabolic inefficiency.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXhsFSit7Y%253D&md5=c5d0a4998b90ed009da370d04d56d9de
    15. 15
      Fedorenko, A.; Lishko, P. V.; Kirichok, Y. Mechanism of fatty-acid-dependent UCP1 uncoupling in brown fat mitochondria. Cell 2012, 151, 400– 413,  DOI: 10.1016/j.cell.2012.09.010
      [Crossref], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.

      Matsuno-Yagi, A.; Hatefi, Y. Uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation: Different effects of lipophilic weak acids and electrogenic ionophores on the kinetics of atp synthesis. Biochemistry 1989, 28, 4367– 4374,  DOI: 10.1021/bi00436a037
      [ACS Full Text ], Google Scholar

    17. 17
      Parker, V. H. Effect of nitrophenols and halogenophenols on the enzymic activity of rat-liver mitochondria. Biochem. J. 1958, 69, 306– 311,  DOI: 10.1042/bj0690306
      [Crossref], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    18. 18
      Hemker, H. C. Lipid solubility as a factor influencing the activity of uncoupling phenols. Biochim. Biophys. Acta 1962, 63, 46– 54,  DOI: 10.1016/0006-3002(62)90337-2

      Chopineaux-Courtois, V.; Reymond, F.; Bouchard, G.; Carrupt, P.; Testa, B.; Girault, H. H. Effects of charge and intramolecular structure on the lipophilicity of nitrophenols. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1999, 121, 1743– 17467,  DOI: 10.1021/ja9836139

    20. 20
      Casey, J. R.; Grinstein, S.; Orlowski, J. Sensors and regulators of intracellular ph. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell Biol. 2010, 11, 50– 61,  DOI: 10.1038/nrm2820
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      20
      Sensors and regulators of intracellular pH
      Casey, Joseph R.; Grinstein, Sergio; Orlowski, John
      Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology (2010), 11 (1), 50-61CODEN: NRMCBP; ISSN:1471-0072. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Protons dictate the charge and structure of macromols. and are used as energy currency by eukaryotic cells. The unique function of individual organelles therefore depends on the establishment and stringent maintenance of a distinct pH. This, in turn, requires a means to sense the prevailing pH and to respond to deviations from the norm with effective mechanisms to transport, produce, or consume proton equiv. A dynamic, finely tuned balance between proton-extruding and proton-importing processes underlies pH homeostasis not only in the cytosol, but in other cellular compartments as well.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsFaqtL3K&md5=e2812e3d37793d358456b4f3e0ee3f8c
    21. 21
      Turrens, J. F. Mitochondrial formation of reactive oxygen species. J. Physiol. 2003, 552, 335– 344,  DOI: 10.1113/jphysiol.2003.049478
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      21
      Mitochondrial formation of reactive oxygen species
      Turrens, Julio F.
      Journal of Physiology (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2003), 552 (2), 335-344CODEN: JPHYA7; ISSN:0022-3751. (Cambridge University Press)
      A review. The redn. of O2 to H2O proceeds via 1 electron at a time. In the mitochondrial respiratory chain, complex IV (cytochrome oxidase) retains all partially reduced intermediates until full redn. is achieved. Other redox centers in the electron transport chain, however, may leak electrons to oxygen, partially reducing this mol. to the superoxide anion (O2-). Even though O2- is not a strong oxidant, it is a precursor of most other reactive O species (ROS), and it also becomes involved in the propagation of oxidative chain reactions. Despite the presence of various antioxidant defences, the mitochondrion appears to be the main intracellular source of these oxidants. This review describes the main mitochondrial sources of ROS and the antioxidant defences that have evolved to prevent oxidative damage in all of the mitochondrial compartments. The authors also discuss various physiol. and pathol. scenarios resulting from an increased steady state concn. of mitochondrial oxidants.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXps1ehtLc%253D&md5=2f3ce8c14e95cd532aeabd2494594c6e
    22. 22
      Figarola, J. L.; Singhal, P.; Rahbar, S.; Gugiu, B. G.; Awasthi, S.; Singhal, S. S. COH-SR4 reduces body weight, improves glycemic control and prevents hepatic steatosis in high fat diet-induced obese mice. PLoS One 2013, 8, e83801,  DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0083801
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      22
      COH-SR4 reduces body weight, improves glycemic control and prevents hepatic steatosis in high fat diet-induced obese mice
      Figarola, James Lester; Singhal, Preeti; Rahbar, Samuel; Gugiu, Bogdan Gabriel; Awasthi, Sanjay; Singhal, Sharad S.
      PLoS One (2013), 8 (12), e83801/1-e83801/12, 12 pp.CODEN: POLNCL; ISSN:1932-6203. (Public Library of Science)
      Obesity is a chronic metabolic disorder caused by imbalance between energy intake and expenditure, and is one of the principal causative factors in the development of metabolic syndrome, diabetes and cancer. COH-SR4 ("SR4") is a novel investigational compd. that has anti-cancer and anti-adipogenic properties. In this study, the effects of SR4 on metabolic alterations in high fat diet (HFD)-induced obese C57BL/J6 mice were investigated. Oral feeding of SR4 (5 mg/kg body wt.) in HFD mice for 6 wk significantly reduced body wt., prevented hyperlipidemia and improved glycemic control without affecting food intake. These changes were assocd. with marked decreases in epididymal fat mass, adipocyte hypertrophy, increased plasma adiponectin and reduced leptin levels. SR4 treatment also decreased liver triglycerides, prevented hepatic steatosis, and normalized liver enzymes. Western blots demonstrated increased AMPK activation in liver and adipose tissues of SR4-treated HFD obese mice, while gene analyses by real time PCR showed COH-SR4 significantly suppressed the mRNA expression of lipogenic genes such as sterol regulatory element binding protein-1c (Srebf1), acetyl-CoA carboxylase (Acaca), peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (Pparg), fatty acid synthase (Fasn), stearoyl-CoA desaturase 1 (Scd1), carnitine palmitoyltransferase 1a (Cpt1a) and 3-hydroxy-3-methyl-glutaryl-CoA reductase (Hmgcr), as well as gluconeogenic genes phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase 1 (Pck1) and glucose-6-phosphatase (G6pc) in the liver of obese mice. In vitro, SR4 activates AMPK independent of upstream kinases liver kinase B1 (LKB1) and Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase kinase β (CaMKKβ). Together, these data suggest that SR4, a novel AMPK activator, may be a promising therapeutic compd. for treatment of obesity, fatty liver disease, and related metabolic disorders.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXltlygt74%253D&md5=6e6f322a36d6317853298c00e6fc00d0
    23. 23
      Goldgof, M.; Xiao, C.; Chanturiya, T.; Jou, W.; Gavrilova, O.; Reitman, M. L. The chemical uncoupler 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP) protects against diet-induced obesity and improves energy homeostasis in mice at thermoneutrality. J. Biol. Chem. 2014, 289, 19341– 19350,  DOI: 10.1074/jbc.M114.568204
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      23
      The Chemical Uncoupler 2,4-Dinitrophenol (DNP) Protects against Diet-induced Obesity and Improves Energy Homeostasis in Mice at Thermoneutrality
      Goldgof, Margalit; Xiao, Cuiying; Chanturiya, Tatyana; Jou, William; Gavrilova, Oksana; Reitman, Marc L.
      Journal of Biological Chemistry (2014), 289 (28), 19341-19350CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
      The chem. uncoupler 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP) was an effective and widely used wt. loss drug in the early 1930s. However, the physiol. of DNP has not been studied in detail because toxicity, including hyperthermia and death, reduced interest in the clin. use of chem. uncouplers. To investigate DNP action, mice fed a high fat diet and housed at 30 °C (to minimize facultative thermogenesis) were treated with 800 mg/L DNP in drinking water. DNP treatment increased energy expenditure by ∼17%, but did not change food intake. DNP-treated mice weighed 26% less than controls after 2 mo of treatment due to decreased fat mass, without a change in lean mass. DNP improved glucose tolerance and reduced hepatic steatosis without obsd. toxicity. DNP treatment also reduced circulating T3 and T4 levels, Ucp1 expression, and brown adipose tissue activity, demonstrating that DNP-mediated heat generation substituted for brown adipose tissue thermogenesis. At 22 °C, a typical vivarium temp. that is below thermoneutrality, DNP treatment had no effect on body wt., adiposity, or glucose homeostasis. Thus, environmental temp. should be considered when assessing an anti-obesity drug in mice, particularly agents acting on energy expenditure. Furthermore, the beneficial effects of DNP suggest that chem. uncouplers deserve further investigation for the treatment of obesity and its comorbidities.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtFCktL3F&md5=b05473ed8ec1ecc5c4e840fbd2ef85c5
    24. 24
      Kalinovich, A. V.; Shabalina, I. G. Novel mitochondrial cationic uncoupler C4R1 is an effective treatment for combating obesity in mice. Biochemistry 2015, 80, 620– 628,  DOI: 10.1134/S0006297915050156
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      24
      Novel mitochondrial cationic uncoupler C4R1 is an effective treatment for combating obesity in mice
      Kalinovich, A. V.; Shabalina, I. G.
      Biochemistry (Moscow) (2015), 80 (5), 620-628CODEN: BIORAK; ISSN:0006-2979. (SP MAIK Nauka/Interperiodica)
      Obesity is assocd. with premature mortality, impaired quality of life, and large healthcare costs. However, treatment options remain quite limited. Here we studied potential anti-obesity effects of a novel cationic mitochondrial uncoupler, C4R1 (deriv. of rhodamine 19) in C57Bl/6 mice. Obesity was induced by long-term (eight weeks) high fat diet feeding at thermoneutrality. The treated group of mice received consecutively two doses of C4R1 in drinking water (30 and 12-14 μmol/kg daily) during 30 days. Effects of C4R1 were dose-dependent. After six days of C4R1 treatment at dose 30 μmol/kg daily, food intake was reduced by 68%, body wt. by 19%, and fat mass by 21%. Body wt. decrease was explained partly by reduced food intake and partly by increased metab., likely resulting from uncoupling. Body fat redn. upon C4R1 treatment was assocd. with improved lipid utilization estd. from decrease in RQ to the minimal level (0.7). Interestingly, the classical uncoupler 2,4-dinitrophenol at similar dose (27 μmol/kg daily) did not have any effect. Our results are relevant to the search for substances causing mild uncoupling of mitochondria that could be a promising therapeutic strategy to treat obesity.

      25
      Reversal of Hypertriglyceridemia, Fatty Liver Disease, and Insulin Resistance by a Liver-Targeted Mitochondrial Uncoupler
      Perry, Rachel J.; Kim, Taehan; Zhang, Xian-Man; Lee, Hui-Young; Pesta, Dominik; Popov, Violeta B.; Zhang, Dongyan; Rahimi, Yasmeen; Jurczak, Michael J.; Cline, Gary W.; Spiegel, David A.; Shulman, Gerald I.
      Cell Metabolism (2013), 18 (5), 740-748CODEN: CMEEB5; ISSN:1550-4131. (Elsevier Inc.)
      Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) affects one in three Americans and is a major predisposing condition for the metabolic syndrome and type 2 diabetes (T2D). We examd. whether a functionally liver-targeted deriv. of 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP), DNP-Me ether (DNPME), could safely decrease hypertriglyceridemia, NAFLD, and insulin resistance without systemic toxicities. Treatment with DNPME reversed hypertriglyceridemia, fatty liver, and whole-body insulin resistance in high-fat-fed rats and decreased hyperglycemia in a rat model of T2D with a wide therapeutic index. The reversal of liver and muscle insulin resistance was assocd. with redns. in tissue diacylglycerol content and redns. in protein kinase C epsilon (PKCε) and PKCθ activity in liver and muscle, resp. These results demonstrate that the beneficial effects of DNP on hypertriglyceridemia, fatty liver, and insulin resistance can be dissocd. from systemic toxicities and suggest the potential utility of liver-targeted mitochondrial uncoupling agents for the treatment of hypertriglyceridemia, NAFLD, metabolic syndrome, and T2D.

      Suzuki, T.; Kikuchi, H.; Ogura, M.; Homma, M. K.; Oshima, Y.; Homma, Y. Weight loss by PPC-1, a novel small molecule mitochondrial uncoupler derived from slime mold. PLoS One 2015, 10, e0117088,  DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0117088
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      26
      Weight loss by Ppc-1, a novel small molecule mitochondrial uncoupler derived from slime mold
      Suzuki, Toshiyuki; Kikuchi, Haruhisa; Ogura, Masato; Homma, Miwako K.; Oshima, Yoshiteru; Homma, Yoshimi
      PLoS One (2015), 10 (2), e0117088/1-e0117088/16CODEN: POLNCL; ISSN:1932-6203. (Public Library of Science)
      Mitochondria play a key role in diverse processes including ATP synthesis and apoptosis. Mitochondrial function can be studied using inhibitors of respiration, and new agents are valuable for discovering novel mechanisms involved in mitochondrial regulation. Here, we screened small mols. derived from slime molds and other microorganisms for their effects on mitochondrial oxygen consumption. We identified Ppc-1 as a novel mol. which stimulates oxygen consumption without adverse effects on ATP prodn. The kinetic behavior of Ppc-1 suggests its function as a mitochondrial uncoupler. Serial administration of Ppc-1 into mice suppressed wt. gain with no abnormal effects on liver or kidney tissues, and no evidence of tumor formation. Serum fatty acid levels were significantly elevated in mice treated with Ppc-1, while body fat content remained low. After a single administration, Ppc-1 distributes into various tissues of individual animals at low levels. Ppc-1 stimulates adipocytes in culture to release fatty acids, which might explain the elevated serum fatty acids in Ppc-1-treated mice. The results suggest that Ppc-1 is a unique mitochondrial regulator which will be a valuable tool for mitochondrial research as well as the development of new drugs to treat obesity.

      Tao, H.; Zhang, Y.; Zeng, X.; Shulman, G. I.; Jin, S. Niclosamide ethanolamine-induced mild mitochondrial uncoupling improves diabetic symptoms in mice. Nat. Med. 2014, 20, 1263– 1269,  DOI: 10.1038/nm.3699
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      28
      Niclosamide ethanolamine-induced mild mitochondrial uncoupling improves diabetic symptoms in mice
      Tao, Hanlin; Zhang, Yong; Zeng, Xiangang; Shulman, Gerald I.; Jin, Shengkan
      Nature Medicine (New York, NY, United States) (2014), 20 (11), 1263-1269CODEN: NAMEFI; ISSN:1078-8956. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Type 2 diabetes (T2D) has reached an epidemic level globally. Most current treatments ameliorate the hyperglycemic symptom of the disease but are not effective in correcting its underlying cause. One important causal factor of T2D is ectopic accumulation of lipids in metabolically sensitive organs such as liver and muscle. Mitochondrial uncoupling, which reduces cellular energy efficiency and increases lipid oxidn., is an appealing therapeutic strategy. The challenge, however, is to discover safe mitochondrial uncouplers for practical use. Niclosamide is an anthelmintic drug approved by the US Food and Drug Administration that uncouples the mitochondria of parasitic worms. Here we show that niclosamide ethanolamine salt (NEN) uncouples mammalian mitochondria at upper nanomolar concns. Oral NEN increases energy expenditure and lipid metab. in mice. It is also efficacious in preventing and treating hepatic steatosis and insulin resistance induced by a high-fat diet. Moreover, it improves glycemic control and delays disease progression in db/db mice. Given the well-documented safety profile of NEN, our study provides a potentially new and practical pharmacol. approach for treating T2D.

      Anderson, E. J.; Lustig, M. E.; Boyle, K. E.; Woodlief, T. L.; Kane, D. A.; Lin, C.-T.; Price, J. W., III; Kang, L.; Rabinovitch, P. S.; Szeto, H. H.; Houmard, J. A.; Cortright, R. N.; Wasserman, D. H.; Neufer, P. D. Mitochondrial H2O2 emission and cellular redox state link excess fat intake to insulin resistance in both rodents and humans. J. Clin.       [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29
      Mitochondrial H2O2 emission and cellular redox state link excess fat intake to insulin resistance in both rodents and humans
      Anderson, Ethan J.; Lustig, Mary E.; Boyle, Kristen E.; Woodlief, Tracey L.; Kane, Daniel A.; Lin, Chien-Te; Price, Jesse W., III; Kang, Li; Rabinovitch, Peter S.; Szeto, Hazel H.; Houmard, Joseph A.; Cortright, Ronald N.; Wasserman, David H.; Neufer, P. Darrell
      Journal of Clinical Investigation (2009), 119 (3), 573-581CODEN: JCINAO; ISSN:0021-9738. (American Society for Clinical Investigation)
      High dietary fat intake leads to insulin resistance in skeletal muscle, and this represents a major risk factor for type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress have been implicated in the disease process, but the underlying mechanisms are still unknown. Here we show that in skeletal muscle of both rodents and humans, a diet high in fat increases the H2O2-emitting potential of mitochondria, shifts the cellular redox environment to a more oxidized state, and decreases the redox-buffering capacity in the absence of any change in mitochondrial respiratory function. Furthermore, we show that attenuating mitochondrial H2O2 emission, either by treating rats with a mitochondrial-targeted antioxidant or by genetically engineering the overexpression of catalase in mitochondria of muscle in mice, completely preserves insulin sensitivity despite a high-fat diet. These findings place the etiol. of insulin resistance in the context of mitochondrial bioenergetics by demonstrating that mitochondrial H2O2 emission serves as both a gauge of energy balance and a regulator of cellular redox environment, linking intracellular metabolic balance to the control of insulin sensitivity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXivF2ktLw%253D&md5=840b7c1d3d43ef632b9b9bed2024bf9f
    30. 30
      Geisler, J. G.; Marosi, K.; Halpern, J.; Mattson, M. P. DNP, mitochondrial uncoupling, and neuroprotection: A little dab’ll do ya. Alzheimer's Dementia 2017, 13, 582– 591,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jalz.2016.08.001
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      30
      DNP, mitochondrial uncoupling, and neuroprotection: A little dab'll do ya
      Geisler John G; Marosi Krisztina; Halpern Joshua; Mattson Mark P
      Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association (2017), 13 (5), 582-591 ISSN:.
      Recent findings have elucidated roles for mitochondrial uncoupling proteins (UCPs) in neuronal plasticity and resistance to metabolic and oxidative stress. UCPs are induced by bioenergetic challenges such as caloric restriction and exercise and may protect neurons against dysfunction and degeneration. The pharmacological uncoupler 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP), which was once prescribed to >100,000 people as a treatment for obesity, stimulates several adaptive cellular stress-response signaling pathways in neurons including those involving the brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), the transcription factor cyclic AMP response element-binding protein (CREB), and autophagy. Preclinical data show that low doses of DNP can protect neurons and improve functional outcome in animal models of Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases, epilepsy, and cerebral ischemic stroke. Repurposing of DNP and the development of novel uncoupling agents with hormetic mechanisms of action provide opportunities for new breakthrough therapeutic interventions in a range of acute and chronic insidious neurodegenerative/neuromuscular conditions, all paradoxically at body weight-preserving doses.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2sznvVSnsg%253D%253D&md5=07702b6c63526780a844b3df2f361dae
